Fig. 1 (a) XRD pattern, (b) Raman spectra, (c) and (d) SEM images of coke. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) 13C NMR spectrum of coke, (b), (c) and (d) 13C NMR peak fitting diagram of coke. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Different contact modes between perovskite LSF-0.4-Sol-gel and coke catalyze coke combustion, (a) coke conversion rate, and (b) gas phase composition. Fig 3 Fig. 4 TG curves of coke conversion catalyzed by different perovskites (a) adding different contents of catalyst LSF-0.4, (b) LSF-x-sol-gel, (c) LSF-x-MOF and (d) perovskites with different structures. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Different catalysts catalyze coke of (a) Coke conversion rate curve and (b) DTG curve. (c) The ignition point, burnout point and comprehensive combustion index of catalytic coke. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The activation energy of coke was calculated by (a) Freeman-Carroll differential method and (b) Coats-Redfern integral method. Fig 6 Fig. 7 O2-TPD spectra of three types of (a) LSF-0.4-MOF, (b) LKS0.17F1.5-MOF, (c) LSF-0.6-Sol-gel and (d) Oxygen species area percentage. (e) oxygen content and (f) corresponding average oxidation state of iron in perovskite determined by iodometric titration. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Diagram of oxygen vacancy formation at different sites of (a) LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 and (c) La0.6Sr0.4FeO3. Structural model of O2 adsorption on oxygen vacancies of (b) LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 and (d) La0.6Sr0.4FeO3. (e) The adsorption energy of O2 adsorbed on oxygen vacancies in perovskite. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Structural model of O2 adsorption on oxygen vacancies of La0.6Sr0.4FeO3 and. LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Weight variation curve of oxygen release regeneration process of (a) LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, (b) LSF-0.4-MOF and (c) LSK0.17F1.5−MOF. (d) Cycle weight loss diagram of perovskite. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Mechanism and pathway speculation of perovskite catalyzed coke combustion. Fig 11 Fig. 12 (a) Coke conversion rate and (b) Product selectivity. (c) XRD patterns and (d) Fe 2p and (e) O1s XPS spectra of fresh, used and regenerated LSK0.17F1.5−MOF. SEM images of (f) coke, (g) used coke, (h) LSK0.17F1.5−MOF and (i) regenerated LSK0.17F1.5−MOF. Coke catalytic gasification is an efficient method of burning coke. The core of this technology is the preparation of efficient and stable catalysts. A series of different type La-Fe-based perovskite catalysts, including ABO3 (La1- x Sr x FeO3, LaK0.04Sr0.25FeO3), R-P (LaK1.7Sr0.2Fe1.7O6) and A2B2O6 (LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6, LaKSr0.2Fe1.8O6) were prepared by sol-gel method and calcination of metal-organic framework (MOF) precursor method. The activity of perovskite catalytic coke was tested by thermogravimetric analysis and tubular reactor. Among them, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF has the best catalytic activity, with T10, T50, and T90 values of 610.65 °C, 666.86 °C, and 705.84 °C, respectively. LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF not only improves coke conversion but also reduces reaction temperature. DFT and experimental results show that doped K and Sr metals promote the formation of many active sites (oxygen vacancies) on the surface of LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF, which reduces the adsorption energy of O2 molecules, realizes the oxygen exchange kinetics. The oxygen release regeneration process is achieved between perovskite lattice oxygen and O2 molecules. These processes synergistically promote coke conversion. In addition, it also has strong stable regeneration performance. These results provide a promising strategy for designing and preparing efficient and low-cost catalysts for the practical application of coke removal. Introduction The core of ethylene production is the ethylene cracking process, which uses naphtha and light diesel oil as raw materials in the cracking furnace tube at high temperature dehydrogenation or chain break reaction to produce ethylene, propylene, fuel gas, and other products. Coking occurs when the coke produced by the pyrolysis of hydrocarbon fuel accumulates in the furnace tube [1–3]. The cross section area of the ethylene cracking reactor reduces as coke is formed, increasing the thermal resistance of the furnace tube and decreasing the heat transfer coefficient. Higher wall temperature is required at the same outlet temperature of the cracking furnace pipe, which increases fuel consumption and leads to the emergence of carburizing and local overheating of the furnace [4–6]. It can also jam the furnace tube, restricting feed and disrupting ethylene synthesis [7]. Therefore, the process of coke removal is the core of the research. At the moment, the primary methods for removing coke from ethylene cracking furnace tubes are inhibiting coking, online cleaning, and coke burning [8–9]. Because both inhibiting coking and online cleaning can not entirely eliminate coke, the burning coke procedure is unavoidable. Because the coke generated in the furnace tube has a stable structure, it must be roasted at high temperatures. Excessive temperature will cause a large amount of heat to accumulate in the furnace tube and damage the furnace tube. As a result, developing a catalyst to lower the burning temperature is a scientific issue. The perovskite type oxide (ABO3) has strong O2− and electron transport properties, as well as high chemical stability and inexpensive cost. The valence state at the B position may be changed by adding a metal cation at the A position, resulting in a high number of oxygen vacancies, the formation of an O2− transfer channel, and the promotion of O2− transfer [10–11]. La(1- x )Ag x CoO3 perovskite was prepared by doping Ag+ at the A site, which promoted the formation of oxygen vacancy, reduced the activation energy of the combustion reaction and promoted the soot conversion [12]. Metal doped La-Co-based perovskite is prepared, and doped K + reduces the formation energy of oxygen vacancy, promoting the formation of oxygen vacancy on the surface of perovskite, and improving the adsorption and activation ability of oxygen [13].Therefore, alkaline earth metals and alkaline earth metals are doped in perovskite to promote the formation of oxygen vacancies and increase the concentration of reactive oxygen species. This paper investigates the impact of alternative preparation techniques and structure of La-Fe-based perovskite on the conversion rate of coke and combustion temperature. And the mechanism of coke combustion catalyzed by perovskite was investigated in detail by DFT calculation and experiments. This approach introduces a novel idea for heterogeneous molecular catalysis. Experimental Experimental reagents The main reagents includes: La(NO3)3·6H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Sr(NO3)2, K3Fe(CN)6, citric acid (CA), disodium ethylene diamine tetraacetate (EDTA), NH3∙H2O and KNO3 were of analytical grade and obtained from Tianjin Damao chemical reagent factory. The coke used in the evaluation process is from No.1 Chemical Plant of PetroChina Daqing Petrochemical Company. Distilled water is prepared in the laboratory. Preparation of perovskite The catalysts used in this experiment are mainly divided into three categories. (1) La1- x Sr x FeO3 (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1) prepared by the sol-gel method, after a certain stoichiometric ratio of metal nitrate is dissolved in deionized water, a certain amount of citric acid is added, stirring until uniform, and then ammonia is added to adjust the pH to 7. The solution is stirred in the oil bath at 80 °C to form a gel, and dried at 60 °C for 24 h to obtain precursor. Finally, perovskite is prepared by air calcination at 800 °C. (2) La1- x Sr x FeO3 (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1) prepared by the calcination MOF precursor method, the detailed preparation process and characterization results of the experiment were as reported in our previous works [14]. (3) On the basis of the second system, a certain amount of K and Sr metals are doped in the A site, and perovskite with different structures (LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6, LaK1.7Sr0.2Fe1.7O6, LaK0.04Sr0.25FeO3 and LaKSr0.2Fe1.8O6) prepared by the calcination MOF precursor method. Abbreviated as LSF-x-Sol-gel (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1), LSF-x-MOF (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1), LKS0.17F1.5−MOF, LK1.7S0.2F1.7−MOF, LK0.04S0.25F-MOF, and LKS0.2F1.8−MOF. Coke and steam catalytic reaction via perovskite The experiments were carried out in a thermogravimetric analyzer presented in Fig. S1. La-Fe-based perovskite and coke were ground to 110–130 mesh (0.14–0.111 mm) in a planetary ball mill respectively and are uniformly mixed according to a certain mass ratio. Then sample was placed in thermogravimetric analyzer, under the air atmosphere, program the temperature of the sample to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The coke conversion rate and weight loss rate were calculated from the TG-DTG data, and the coke conversion rate was calculated by Eq. (1): (1) x = m 0 + m 1 − m 2 m 0 · 100 % Where, m0 is the mass of coke before reaction, g; m1 is the mass of perovskite, g; m2 is the total mass after reaction, g; and x are the conversion rate of coke,%. DFT calculations The generalized gradient approximation with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) was used to model the electron exchange and correlation. The projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials was used to describe the ionic cores. Valence electrons were described by a plane wave basis with an energy cutoff of 450 eV. Partial occupancies of the Kohn−Sham orbitals were allowed using the Gaussian smearing method and a width of 0.05 eV. The electronic energy was considered self-consistent when the energy change was smaller than 10−4 eV [15]. The adsorption energies (Eads) were calculated by (2) Eads=Ead/sub-Ead-Esub Where Ead/sub, Ead, and Esub are the total energies of the optimized adsorbate/substrate system, the adsorbate in the structure, and the clean substrate, respectively. Dynamics calculation Coats-Redfern integral and Freeman-Carroll methods were used to investigate the kinetics of coke combustion, respectively. Due to the complex composition of coke formed in ethylene cracking process, and the composition is not uniform. Therefore, selecting the axisymmetric shrinking model [16,17], dynamics analysis of samples was performed by the Coats-Redfern integral method, and obtained by the Coats-Redfern approximation method [18–20]: (3) ln ( 3 [ 1 − ( 1 − x ) 1 / 3 ] T 2 ) = − E R ⋅ 1 T + ln A R β E Freeman-Carroll method was used to calculate coke combustion kinetic parameters [21]: (4) ln [ d x d T / ( 1 − x ) n ] = ln [ A β ] − E R T Where x is the coke conversion rate, %, T is reaction temperature, K; A is pre-exponential factor, s-1; R is gas constant, 8.314 J/mol;β is heating rate, K/min, E is activation energy, KJ/mol. Characterizations The structures of the coke materials were represented using 13C NMR. The proton resonance frequency is 400.13 MHz, the CP/MAS wideband solid probe can detect 31P-15 N. The magnetic field drift is less than 4.0 Hz/hour, and the frequency resolution is less than 0.005 Hz. The measured chemical displacement ranges were −50–250 ppm. 600 MHz solid state NMR spectrum instrument (JNM-ECZ600R, Japan) was used for the measurement. C, H, O, N and S elementals analysis were performed on coke raw materials via elemental analyses instrument (Vario Macro Cube, Germany). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of perovskite oxide samples was performed using Cu Kα as the radiation source. The wavelength λ was 0.1542 Å, tube voltage was 40 kV, current was 40 mA, 2θ scanning range was 5–80°, and the scanning rate was 10°/min. D8 Venture X-ray Diffraction (XRD) instrument (BRUKER/AXS, Germany) was used for the measurement. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) (JSM-6360LA, JEOL, Japan) was used to observe the morphology of the samples at the accelerating voltage of 10–20 kV and the amplification power of 2000–50,000 kX. Raman Spectrometer (DXR, Thermo Scientific, USA) was used to analyze the structure of coke. TG/DTA/DSC analyzer (HTG-1, Beijing Hengjiu Experimental Equipment Co. Ltd., China) was used to analyze the thermal performance of samples. Gas chromatography (GC) (9790 plus, Zhejiang Fuli Analytical Instrument Co. Ltd., China) was used to analyze gas composition. Oxygen temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) (ASAP2920, Micromeritics, America). Prior to the O2-TPD analysis, the perovskite was programmatically heated from room temperature to 500 °C with oxygen for 30 min, and cooled to 100 °C. Then 20 vol.% O2 was introduced into the system and absorbed for 40 min. After the oxygen was adsorbed, the temperature rises to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min after being purged with He (40 mL/min) for 30 min, and the TCD detector monitors variations in O2 concentration. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Thermo Fisher Scientific with K-alpha radiation (1486.6 eV) as the excitation source. The binding energy of the samples was calibrated according to C 1 s XPS at a binding energy of 284.6 eV. Results and discussion Properties of coke The XRD pattern Fig. 1 a shows that the coke contains two different carbon types, graphite carbon and amorphous carbon, and the high crystallinity indicates a considerable degree of graphitization and crystal in the coke structure, which is due to the strong condensation polymerization at high temperature [22]. From Fig. 1b, it can be seen that the Raman spectra contained two predominant peaks, namely D1 (at 1300 cm−1) and G (at 1600 cm−1) [23]. The former represents the vibration intensity of the disordered lattice, and the latter represents the vibration intensity of the ordered lattice, this is consistent with the results of XRD. The morphology of the coke in the ethylene cracking furnace is shown in Fig. 1c-d. The morphology of coke is irregular, consisting of filamentous, flaky, and spherical structures, which are formed by different types of coking mechanisms. The grain size of coke range is 1–2 μ m. The structure is relatively dense. The results of elemental analysis of ethylene cracking furnace coke are shown in Table S1. The main component of coke is C, with the content of 94.915 wt.%, the content of H element is 1.345 wt.%, the content of O element and S element is little, and there is no N element. The 13C NMR spectrum of ethylene cracking furnace coke are shown in Fig. 2 . The types of carbon in coke are divided into fatty carbon region (δ=0–90 ppm), aromatic carbon region (δ=90–160 ppm) and carbonyl carbon region (δ=160–220 ppm) [24]. To analyze the distribution of the carbon structure in coke and in combination with the attribution of the chemical displacement of the carbon structure, Mestre Nova 11.0 software is used to perform peak fitting and normalization on the spectrogram to obtain the distribution of various types of carbon structure in coke, the results are shown in Table S2. As can be seen from Table S2, the chemical shift δ is attributed to fatty carbon in the range of 22–35 ppm and 36–50 ppm. The chemical shift δ at 25.88 ppm, 28.99 ppm and 31.21 ppm is attributed to the methylene (-CH2) group in the fatty region. Chemical shift in the δ=36–50 ppm range, there is a weak resonance signal, attributed to methylene carbon or quaternary carbon. The chemical shift is in the range of δ=50–110 ppm and is attributed to weak alkoxy carbon. It can be seen that the functional group in the coke of ethylene cracking furnace is mainly fatty carbon, with a content of 70.53 %, the second is aromatic carbonyl carbon, which is 17.42 %, and the carbonyl carbon content was at least 11.98 %. Optimization of combustion process parameters for perovskite catalyzed coke Contact mode between perovskite and coke Exploring the effect of the contact method between perovskite LSF-0.4-Sol-gel and coke on the conversion rate of coke, the contact methods between catalyst and coke are as follows: catalyst and coke are pressed into contact separately, catalyst and coke are mixed evenly, and catalyst and coke are mixed evenly and pressed into flakes under a pressure of 10 MPa, with a diameter of 2 cm, as shown in the illustration in Fig. 3 a. The reaction between coke and O2 was catalyzed under three different contact methods, and the coke conversion rate is shown in Fig. 3a. It can be seen that compared with the separate pressing method (67.65 %) and the loose contact method (74.86 %), the catalyst and coke pressing method have the highest coke conversion rate of 87.67 %. The experimental results indicate that the contact mode of the pressing plate is beneficial for coke conversion, possibly due to the multiple contact sites between the coke particles and the catalyst. The gas phase product composition of the combustion reaction between perovskite and coke under different contact modes is shown in Fig. 3b. From the figure, it can be seen that the gas phase products are mainly CO and CO2. The contact method gradually decreases the selectivity of CO and increases the selectivity of CO2 from separate tablet pressing to mixed tablet pressing. The maximum selectivity of CO2 during mixed tablet contact is 99.23 %. This indicates that perovskite LSF-0.4-Sol-gel and coke compression are beneficial for the conversion of coke into CO2. Effect of catalyst content The TG curves of coke conversion catalyzed by different concentrations of LSF-0.4-Sol-gel perovskite (1 wt.%, 3 wt.%, 5 wt.%, and 7 wt.%) are shown in Fig. 4 a. With the increase of catalyst content, the coke conversion rate shows a trend of first increasing and then decreasing. When the amount of catalyst added is 5 wt.% and the reaction temperature is 900 °C, the maximum conversion rate of coke is 98.36 %. When the catalyst content is 7 wt.%, the coke conversion rate decreases to 79.71 %. This may be because too many catalysts hinder the contact between air and coke. Therefore, the optimal catalyst addition amount is 5 wt.%. Effect of catalyst Explore the effects of different preparation methods (sol-gel and MOF methods) and perovskite structures on coke conversion rate, as shown in Fig. 4b-d. As the temperature increases, the TG curve of perovskite catalyzed coke conversion mainly consists of three stages: (a) In the first stage, the weight loss range is around 50 °C-200 °C, indicating that the addition of perovskite has little effect on this stage, as this is mainly due to the physical adsorption of water on the surface of the coke during this stage. (b) The second stage is the rapid weight loss stage, where some amorphous carbon in the coke reacts with oxygen to generate gaseous products CO and CO2. (c) The third stage, which is the gradual flattening of the curve, indicates that the combustion of the coke is basically completed, and there may be residual unreacted graphite carbon and some amorphous carbon. Part of the curve did not show the third stage because the conversion rate was slow within the 900 °C range. The effect of different preparation methods of perovskite on coke conversion is shown in Fig. 4b-c. It can be seen from the figure that the catalytic activity of perovskite prepared by MOF method is better than that prepared by sol-gel method, which may be due to the rich pore structure of perovskite prepared by MOF, which is conducive to air adsorption. From Fig. 4b, it can be seen that when adding perovskite LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, the coke conversion curve shows a gentle stage with a coke conversion rate of 93.25 % in the range of 804 °C-900 °C. The remaining perovskite LSF-x did not show a gentle stage at 900 °C, and the coke conversion rate from low to high was: LSF-0 (79.02 %) <LSF-0.8 (85.06 %) <LSF-0.2 (85.09 %) <LSF-1 (85.25 %) <LSF-0.4 (89.32 %). The experimental results indicate that LSF-0.6 has strong catalytic activity for coke conversion. The catalytic coke conversion curve of perovskite LSF-x (0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1) prepared by MOF method is shown in Fig. 4c. When the Sr doping amount is 0.4, the coke conversion rate is 100 %, indicating strong perovskite activity and complete coke conversion. The results indicate that the perovskite prepared by the MOF method promotes coke conversion. Further investigate the effect of different types of perovskite (ABO3, A2B2O6 and R-P) prepared by MOF method on coke conversion rate, as shown in Fig. 4d. At reaction temperature of 900 °C, the coke conversion rate from low to high is as follows: LKS0.2F1.8 (70.43 %) < LK0.04S0.25F (82.76 %) < LK1.7S0.2F1.7 (87.24 %) < LKS0.17F1.5−MOF (100 %). Among them, the coke conversion rate of double perovskite (LKS0.17F1.5−MOF) reached 100 % at a reaction temperature of 784 °C. The results indicate that double perovskite LKS0.17F1.5−MOF has high catalytic activity, which not only increases the coke conversion rate but also reduces the reaction temperature. Characteristic value calculation From the results in Fig. 5 , it can be seen that the catalysts with better catalytic performance in the three systems are LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, LSF-0.4-MOF, and LKS0.17F1.5−MOF, respectively. To investigate the catalytic activity of perovskite, values of T10, T50, and T90 were used to evaluate the corresponding temperatures for conversion rates of 10 %, 50 %, and 90 % [25], as shown in Fig. 5a and Table S3. Table S3 lists the T10, T50, and T90 values of coke as 717.20 °C, 782.67 °C, and 847.58 °C, respectively, with a coke conversion rate of only 92.65 %. Adding the above catalysts in the coke combustion reaction significantly reduced the T10, T50, and T90 values of coke combustion, and the conversion rate of coke was higher than 92.65 %. This indicates that the prepared catalyst exhibits excellent activity during the coke combustion reaction process. Among them, LKS0.17F1.5−MOF has the best catalytic activity, with T10, T50, and T90 values of 610.65 °C, 666.86 °C, and 705.84 °C, respectively. Fig. 5b shows the reaction rate (DTG) curve of coke combustion catalyzed by the above catalyst. From the graph, it can be seen that the temperature required to reach the maximum carbon conversion rate varies from large to small: without catalyst (810.6 °C) > LSF-0.6-Sol-gel (743.3 °C) > LSF-0.4-MOF (706.8 °C) > LKS0.17F1.5−MOF (662.0 °C). Compared with the absence of catalyst, the gasification rate is significantly increased with the addition of catalyst, while reducing the reaction temperature at which the carbon conversion rate reaches its maximum. Among them, LKS0.17F1.5−MOF has strong catalytic activity, which is consistent with the above results. This is because the A-site of LKS0.17F1.5−MOF perovskite is doped with alkali metal (K) and alkaline earth metal (Sr), which promotes the conversion of coke. At the same time, it has abundant oxygen vacancies, reducing the adsorption energy of oxygen on the surface of coke, thereby promoting contact between oxygen and coke. The combustion curve of coke was analyzed using the combined definition method of thermogravimetry differential thermogravimetry (TG-DTG) [26], as shown in Fig. S2. The calculation results indicate that the ignition point, burnout point, and comprehensive combustion characteristic index of coke are 715 °C, 841 °C, and 0.13 × 10−8 (%∙min−2∙ °C − 3), respectively. The data in Fig. 5a was calculated using the above method, and the results are shown in Fig. 5c and Table S4. The addition of catalyst significantly reduces the ignition and burnout points of coke, indicating that the catalyst effectively reduces the reaction temperature. In addition, the comprehensive combustion index has also significantly increased, indicating the promotion of coke combustion. The maximum comprehensive combustion index of coke with LKS0.17F1.5−MOF catalyst added is 9.13 × 10−8 (%∙min−2∙ °C − 3) indicates that the LKS0.17F1.5−MOF catalyst has the best catalytic performance for coke combustion. In order to further study the effect of perovskite on the combustion rate of coke, Coats-Redfern integral method and Freeman-Carroll differential method were used to calculate the combustion reaction kinetics of coke, as shown in Fig. 6 . The activation energy (Ea), pre-exponential factor (lnA) and correlation coefficient (r2 ) are shown in Table S5. As can be seen from Fig. 6a, that the correlation coefficient of the kinetics fitting curve is greater than 0.95, indicating that the first-order reaction kinetics model is feasible. As can be seen from Table S5, the activation energy Ea of coke is 231.13 KJ/mol and lnA is 8.34 s − 1 when without catalyst is added. The activation energy of coke combustion decreased significantly after the addition of catalyst, indicating that the catalyst accelerated the reaction rate of coke combustion [27–28]. It can be seen from the Fig. 6b that the kinetic fitting curves calculated by Coats-Redfern integral method have good correlation, and the correlation coefficient (r2) is greater than 0.97, indicating that the coke combustion reaction conforms to the first-order kinetic model. As can be seen from Table S5, the values of Ea and lnA calculated by the Coats-Redfern integral method are slightly larger than those obtained by the Freeman-Carroll differential method, but the calculation trend of the two methods is consistent. The activation energy of coke combustion reaction from small to large is as follows: LKS0.17F1.5−MOF < LSF-0.4-MOF < LSF-0.6-Sol-gel < without catalyst. When the addition amount of LKS0.17F1.5−MOF is 5 wt.%, the activation energy of coke combustion reaction is the lowest, which is 138.84 kJ/mol, which is 147.99 kJ/mol lower than when no catalyst is added, indicating that LKS0.17F1.5 has the highest catalytic activity. Analysis of catalytic performance of perovskite O2-TPD analysis Fig. 7 a-c shows the O2-TPD spectra of three types of perovskite (LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, LSF-0.4-MOF and LKS0.17F1.5−MOF) catalysts prepared. It can be seen that the oxygen species of perovskite are mainly divided into three types. The desorption peaks within the range of 100–300 °C are attributed to the physical/chemical surface adsorbed oxygen, named α-O [29–31]. The desorption peaks within the range of 300–600 °C are attributed to the surface vacancies, or superficial lattice oxygen, named β-O. The adsorption peak is attributed to bulk lattice oxygen above 600 °C, named γ-O [32,33]. The peak area percentage of oxygen species is shown in Fig. 7d. From the figure, it can be seen that the adsorbed oxygen content of the sample is in descending order: LKS0.17F1.5−MOF (49.99 %)>LSF-0.4-MOF (42.28 %)>LSF-0.6-Sol-gel (36.28 %). The results clearly indicate that LKS0.17F1.5−MOF has the highest concentration of reactive oxygen species, indicating the optimal oxygen activation ability of LKS0.17F1.5. Collectively, the introduction of oxygen vacancies will facilitate the activation of oxygen species and further activate the surface oxygen species on perovskite. The oxygen vacancies and average valence states of B site Fe in perovskite (LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, LSF-0.4-MOF and LKS0.17F1.5−MOF) determined by iodometric titration [34], as shown in Fig. 7e-f. From Fig. 7e, it can be seen that the δ values of the three types of perovskites are all greater than zero, presenting an oxygen deficient state (oxygen vacancies in the perovskite layer). The oxygen vacancies of LSF-0.6-Sol-gel,LSF-0.4-MOF and LKS0.17F1.5−MOF perovskites are 0.33, 0.78, and 0.97, respectively. The average valence states of Fe corresponding to the three types of perovskites are 2.74, 2.44, and 3.81, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7f. The experimental results indicate that LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF perovskite has abundant oxygen vacancies and strong oxidation properties, which is consistent with the results of O2-TPD. DFT calculation of O2 adsorption energy As can be seen from Fig. 8 a, there are three oxygen vacancy formation sites of the perovskite LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O3, namely LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 1 and LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 3. The structural models of oxygen molecules adsorbed at different adsorption sites on the surface of LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 catalyst are shown in the Fig. 8b. As can be seen from Fig. 8e, the adsorption energy of oxygen adsorbed at LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0 is the lowest, which is −1.322 eV. The results showed that oxygen molecules was mainly adsorbed at LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0. Due to the high symmetry of La0.6Sr0.4FeO3 catalyst, there are two sites for oxygen vacancy formation, namely La0.6Sr0.4FeO3-Site 0 and La0.6Sr0.4FeO3-Site 1, as shown in Fig. 8c. And the structural models of O2 adsorbed at different oxygen vacancy sites of La0.6Sr0.4FeO3 catalyst are shown in Fig. 8d. Compared with La0.6Sr0.4FeO3-Site 1, the adsorption energy of oxygen molecules adsorbed at La0.6Sr0.4FeO3 -Site 1 is lower, which is −0.529 eV. The results show that the adsorption energy barrier of oxygen molecules adsorbed on the surface of LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 catalyst is lower than La0.6Sr0.4FeO3, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 is more favorable for O2 molecules adsorption. As can be seen from Fig. 9 , it can be seen that O2 molecules are adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies of La0.6Sr0.4FeO3-Site 0 and LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0, respectively, with different bond angles of 135.953° and 121.180° The oxygen atoms at the end of the O2 molecules are connected to perovskite oxygen vacancies (La0.6Sr0.4FeO3-Site 0 and LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0) with bond lengths of 2.577 Å and 2.522 Å, respectively. The bond length of O2 molecules adsorption on LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0 oxygen vacancies is shorter, indicating that O2 molecules adsorption on the surface of LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6-Site 0 oxygen vacancies may be stronger. The results show that LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6 is conducive to O2 molecule adsorption, this is consistent with the results in Fig. 8. Evaluation of oxygen-releasing and regeneration performance Three types of perovskites (LSF-0.6-Sol-gel, LSF-0.4-MOF, LSK0.17F1.5−MOF) were evaluated for oxygen releasing-regeneration performance at different temperatures using TG, as shown in Fig. 10 a-c. The weight loss of perovskites during each cycle process is shown in Fig. 10d. It can be seen that with the increase of temperature, the weight loss rate of perovskite shows a trend of first increasing and then decreasing. The results indicate that the oxygen release ability of perovskite also increases first and then decreases. Among them, the oxygen release ability of LSF-0.6-Sol-gel perovskite is the weakest, and its oxygen-releasing and regeneration ability tends to stabilize when the temperature is above 700 °C. The perovskite LSF-0.4-MOF exhibits the strongest oxygen releasing and regeneration ability at temperatures ranging from 500 °C to 600 °C. The results indicate that LSF-0.4-MOF and LSK0.17F1.5−MOF have strong oxygen-releasing and regeneration capabilities at low and high temperatures, respectively. When the reaction temperature is above 600 °C, the oxygen releasing and regeneration ability of perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF is the strongest. Due to the fact that perovskite catalyzed coke combustion reaction is carried out in an air atmosphere and high temperature conditions, perovskite can achieve cyclic release of lattice oxygen and regeneration, thereby promoting coke conversion and improving coke conversion rate. This is consistent with the optimal catalytic performance of LSK0.17F1.5−MOF. Mechanism and pathway speculation of perovskite catalyzed coke combustion reaction The reaction path between coke and air under the condition of no catalyst is shown in Fig. 11 a. Oxygen in the air first diffuses to the outer surface of the coke, and then diffuses to the inner surface of the coke through the pores in the coke particles. Oxygen is adsorbed on the microporous surface of the coke and reacts with the coke to generate CO and CO2. Some of the CO reacts with oxygen to convert into CO2. The generated products diffuse outward through micropores and diffuse into the air through the retention layer, causing partial conversion of coke [35]. The mechanism of coke combustion reaction catalyzed by double perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF is shown in Fig. 11b. Due to the doping of low valence K (alkali metal) and Sr (alkali earth metal) at the A-site of double perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF, which partially replace La3+, perovskite has more oxygen vacancies. The combustion process of coke catalyzed by perovskite mainly consists of four pathways. Path 1: Perovskite oxygen vacancies lose electrons and transfer them to oxygen molecules, reducing the energy barrier for oxygen adsorption, making it easier for oxygen to adsorb on oxygen vacancies to form adsorbed oxygen, and generating oxygen ions to achieve oxygen exchange kinetics on the perovskite surface (O2+4e−+2Vo=2O2−) [36]. Furthermore, oxygen ions react with coke to generate CO and CO2. Path 2: A small amount of lattice oxygen in perovskite is transferred through oxygen vacancies and reacts with the coke interface to generate CO and CO2. Path 3: Fewer lattice oxygen is partially released in perovskite at high temperatures to generate a small amount of oxygen, increasing oxygen concentration and promoting coke conversion. Path 4: Partial lattice oxygen overflows leaving oxygen vacancies. In a high-temperature air atmosphere, oxygen adsorbs on oxygen vacancies to generate oxygen ions that enter the bulk phase of perovskite and achieve regeneration. Perovskite undergoes oxygen release-regeneration cycle at high temperatures to promote coke conversion. The above factors all contribute to the catalytic oxidation of coke by perovskite and exhibit excellent catalytic activity, which is consistent with the catalyst evaluation results in Fig. 5. The reaction process is a dynamic process, where there are many reactive oxygen species (adsorbed oxygen) interacting in perovskite, namely the formation of oxygen vacancies, the release of lattice oxygen, and the filling of lattice oxygen. Therefore, the catalytic activity of K and Sr modified-La-Fe based double perovskite was improved. Regeneration performance evaluation Catalytic stability evaluation The stability of the catalyst is the most important factor for its catalytic performance. The stability of catalyst LSK0.17F1.5−MOF was studied to further explore its performance. Under the same conditions, the stability of catalyst LSK0.17F1.5−MOF was tested through four cyclic experiments. From Fig. 12 a-b, it can be seen that the conversion rate of coke slightly decreases with the increase of the number of cycles. The CO2 selectivity of the gas phase product after 4 cycles slightly decreased by 1.4 %, corresponding to an increase in CO selectivity. The results further indicate that the LSK0.17F1.5−MOF catalyst has strong stability. Crystal phase analysis The XRD spectra of perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF catalytic coke before, after, and after regeneration (1 and 3 times of regeneration) are shown in Fig. 12c. From the graph, it can be seen that both the reacted and regenerated samples exhibit characteristic peaks of perovskite, indicating strong stability of the sample. Compared with the fresh sample, the XRD peak intensity of LSK0.17F1.5−MOF after reaction decreased. After calcination and regeneration in air atmosphere, the XRD characteristic peak intensity of LSK0.17F1.5−MOF returned to almost the same level as the fresh sample. After 3 cycles of catalytic regeneration, the characteristic peaks of the sample slightly decreased. XPS analysis The XPS spectrogram of fresh, spent and regenerated (after 4 redox cycles) LSK0.17F1.5−MOF samples are shown in Fig. 12d-e. The peak areas of Fe 2p and O 1 s were fitted by integration as shown in Table S6. From Fig. 12d and Table S6, it can be seen that after the reaction and regeneration of the perovskite LSK0.17F1.5 sample, the valence states of Fe element are Fe2+, Fe3+ and Fe4+, respectively [37–39]. Compared with the fresh sample, the Fe2+/(Fe3++Fe4+) ratio of the sample after reaction decreased from 0.255 to 0.182, indicating that the oxidation of low-valence iron to high-valence iron in perovskite occurred. After one regeneration of the sample, the Fe2+/(Fe3++Fe4+) ratio was 0.250, almost returning to its original state. The Fe2+/(Fe3++Fe4+) ratio slightly increased to 0.266 after three sample regenerations, indicating that perovskite has strong stability. From Fig. 12e and Table S6, it can be seen that the oxygen species in perovskite mainly include lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen [40,41]. Compared with the fresh sample, the peak position of the sample after reaction shifted to the high binding energy, indicating that the reaction process lost electrons and promoted the adsorption of oxygen. After the sample reaction, the Oads/Olat ratio increased to 2.685, because a small amount of lattice oxygen was released and participated in the reaction during the catalytic reaction, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancies. After the sample is regenerated, oxygen in the air adsorbs on the surface of perovskite, and a portion of electrons to form oxygen ions. Through the oxygen ion transport channel, it supplements perovskite oxygen vacancies and promotes the increase of lattice oxygen. After one regeneration, the sample almost returns to its original state. Compared with fresh samples, the Oads/Olat ratio of the samples after one and three regenerations almost returned to the original state, indicating that the perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF has good stability. Morphological analysis From Fig. 12f it can be seen that the pre-reaction coke morphology is blocky and dense. The surface of the coke after reaction has a clear pore structure, which is because the coke is converted into CO2 (Fig. 12g). From Fig. 12h-i, it can be seen that there is no significant change in the morphology of perovskite LSK0.17F1.5−MOF before and after the reaction. Conclusion In this work, the effects of different preparation methods and structures of alkali metal and alkali earth metal-modified La-Fe-based perovskite on coke combustion were investigated. Among them, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF has the best catalytic activity, with T10, T50, and T90 values of 610.65 °C, 666.86 °C, and 705.84 °C, respectively. LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF perovskite not only increases the comprehensive combustion index of coke but also reduces the activation energy of the reaction. The characterization results reveal that there are more oxygen vacancies on the surface of the LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF catalyst due to the doping of a certain amount of K + and Sr2+ ions, which improve the adsorption and activation ability of oxygen molecule, realizes the oxygen exchange kinetics. In addition, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF exhibits strong oxygen releasing-regeneration ability at high temperatures. These processes synergistically promote coke combustion and achieve in-situ conversion. Importantly, the K and Sr-modified La-Fe-based perovskite catalysts are promising for practical applications in coke combustion owing to their low cost, high activity, and stability. coredata.dc:description: Coke catalytic gasification is an efficient method of burning coke. The core of this technology is the preparation of efficient and stable catalysts. A series of different type La-Fe-based perovskite catalysts, including ABO3 (La1- x Sr x FeO3, LaK0.04Sr0.25FeO3), R-P (LaK1.7Sr0.2Fe1.7O6) and A2B2O6 (LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6, LaKSr0.2Fe1.8O6) were prepared by sol-gel method and calcination of metal-organic framework (MOF) precursor method. The activity of perovskite catalytic coke was tested by thermogravimetric analysis and tubular reactor. Among them, LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF has the best catalytic activity, with T10, T50, and T90 values of 610.65 °C, 666.86 °C, and 705.84 °C, respectively. LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF not only improves coke conversion but also reduces reaction temperature. DFT and experimental results show that doped K and Sr metals promote the formation of many active sites (oxygen vacancies) on the surface of LaKSr0.17Fe1.5O6−MOF, which reduces the adsorption energy of O2 molecules, realizes the oxygen exchange kinetics. The oxygen release regeneration process is achieved between perovskite lattice oxygen and O2 molecules. These processes synergistically promote coke conversion. In addition, it also has strong stable regeneration performance. These results provide a promising strategy for designing and preparing efficient and low-cost catalysts for the practical application of coke removal.
coredata.dc:title: Alkali metal and alkali earth metal-modified La-Fe-based perovskite catalyzed coke combustion
